intro: Campanula litvinskajae, commonly known as the Lithuanian bellflower, is a rare and endangered species native to the forest-steppe regions of Lithuania. It is characterized by its bell-shaped blue to violet flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and partial shade, often found in meadows and forest edges. Due to habitat loss, it is now protected and listed on the IUCN Red List.
